title: Tad Nichols collects water from a cliffside spring
originaltitle: [Tad Nichols collecting water at cliffside (from seep or spring).]
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: Seeps are places where water pushes out from a cliff face. As rain falls on sandstone ground, it percolates down through the porous rock until it reaches a layer of shale, whose sedimentary particulates are gathered too tightly to allow water to pass. The water then moves sideways along the shale surface until it pushes out through the cliff wall. Water can spend years travelling through the rock before it emerges from a seep.
subject: sediment; humans; land; water; spring; land
personalnotes: sediment stores water

title: Tad Nichols sitting on rock steps at Crossing of the Fathers
originaltitle: Tad sitting on rock steps at Crossing of the Fathers [This image appears in Tad's Glen Canyon book on page 136].
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: Tad Nichols sitting on rock steps at a potential Crossing of the Fathers site. In 1776, Franciscan preists, Fathers Escalante and Dominguez wandered along the Colorado River for a month before they found an accessible crossing. The expedition had set out from Santa Fe, New Mexico to search for an overland route to reach a Catholic Mission in Monterrey, California, but was forced to backtrack as winter approached. Indigenous guides had intially led them safely across the river, but on their return their guide, who was 12 years old, suddenly quit after witnessing severe punishment of a servant. Lost and out of supplies, the party was forced to eat their horses.  The exact location of this crossing is unkown, but the Fathers remarked in their journal that the crossing was made possible by carving steps down the sandstone cliffs, and by swimming across a part of the river that had been made narrow by sand bars and the river's bend. The Crossing of the Fathers is now under Lake Powell's waters.
subject: sediment; land; humans; conquistadors
location: Glen Canyon; Crossing of the Fathers
personalnotes: sediment allowed for human movement across the landscape--including colonizer movement

title: Tad Nichols in Dungeon Canyon
originaltitle: [Tad Nichols in Dungeon Canyon; this image appears in Tad's Glen Canyon book on page 119.]
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: Tad Nichols stands at the bottom of Dungeon Canyon. Dungeon Canyon was once one of Glen Canyon's deepest side canyons. It was submerged when the lake backed up behind Glen Canyon Dam after its completion in 1966, but as the lake dries up, Dungeon Canyon is beginning to re-emerge.

title: Beaver dam in Glen Canyon
originaltitle: [Tad Nichols wading, pointing toward beaver dam.]
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: Beavers have been making dams on the Colorado River long before the Bureau of Reclamation built Glen Canyon Dam. But beaver dams are constructed of loose stick piles, not solid concrete, and therefore allow water and small material to pass through. Beaver dams were also temporary; before Glen Canyon Dam, spring floods scoured the landscape,  washing away not only beavers' dams but also the river banks where beavers made their dens, the willow and cottonwood that beavers depend on for food. As a result, there were fewer beavers around Glen Canyon pre-dam. As beaver populations have blossomed, willow has declined, easing the way for  invasive tamarisk to take root.
subject: animals; beavers; humans; dam;

title: Navajo Sandstone
originaltitle: Navajo Sandstone.
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: Navajo Sandstone was blown in on wind systems 190 million years ago, during the Early Jurrasic Period. The crossbedding reaveals these winds originated from the north-north west, and the particulates themselves are well-rounded and fine quartz, evidence of a long journey. Geologists have found zircon in the particulates, which shows they came from the Appalachain mountains, carried by an ancient river system and then blown by desert winds. They formed sand dunes larger than the Sahara, (20m) which will leave no record behind. It is the largest aeolian record on earth. These winds still sculpt the region today. Scientists have shown that much of the sandstone was "churned by insects and trampled by reptiles (Loope and Rowe 2003, p. 223). Evidence of stromatalites has also been found, which are laminated growth structures created by microbes.
subject: land; strata; sandstone; air; water; animals; insects; reptiles; wind
personalnotes: sediment tells the story of wind, of animals, of rain, of ancient rivers, and is made from a place far away!

title: Petroglyph
originaltitle: [Petroglyph - Rectilinear design within circle.]
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: There are countless petroglyphs around Glen Canyon, some of which have been buried by Lake Powell. Petroglyphs were created by the many Indigenous individuals and communities that have dwelt with Glen Canyon, and often times mark a culturally or personally importance place. The contrast in color between the glyph and the surrounding stone relies on scraping away the desert varnish, which forms when the rock interacts with air, water, minerals, and microorganisims over thousands of years.
subject: petroglyph; strata; land; humans; art
personalnotes: to cut out petroglyphs requires both the absence and presence of sediment. One must get rid of some sediment and release it into the land, but sediment must first exist in hardened rock. Entrusts the human story to sediment and binds humans and and sediment and language and the object carved together and locks it in the landscape. This is quite different than paper, which can be transported, which does not return material to the land in the same way, which does not locate the object in the geologic record.

repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: Soft sandstone often develop hollows across its face called tafoni. These caverns are scooped out by weathering processes such as water, wind, and chemical reactions, revealing where sediment particulates were bound together less firmly.
subject: sediment; land
personalnotes: here the absence of silt tells us something about its interactions with its environment

In 1776, Franciscan preists, Fathers Escalante and Dominguez wandered along the Colorado River for a month before they found an accessible crossing. The expedition had set out from Santa Fe, New Mexico to search for an overland route to reach a Catholic Mission in Monterrey, California, but was forced to backtrack as winter approached. Indigenous guides had intially led them safely across the river, but on their return their guide, who was 12 years old, suddenly quit after witnessing severe punishment of a servant. Lost and out of supplies, the party was forced to eat their horses.  The exact location of this crossing is unkown, but the Fathers remarked in their journal that the crossing was made possible by carving steps down the sandstone cliffs, and by swimming across a part of the river that had been made narrow by sand bars and the river's bend. title: Pedestal rock formation near Willow Creek
originaltitle: Table at head of Willow Creek.
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: Table or pedestal rocks such as this one form when sandstone's lower layers erode more readily than its upper layers. Particulates in the lower strata may be cemented together less tightly. If the sandsone is composed of quartz sediment, it is likely to be more durable and erosion resistant; sandstone made of feldspar and clay tends to be less tightly bound. Pedestal rocks can also form as wind plucks sand from the ground and blasts the rock. Typically sand blasts are strongest at lower heights.
subject: sediment; land; strata
location: Glen Canyon; Willow Creek; Escalante Canyon
personalnotes: sediment shows us in form what it is made of. sediment also carves itself

title: Forbidding Canyon
originaltitle: [Forbidding Canyon.]
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: "An adequate conception of the ruggedness of this particular region cannot be conveyed in words," wrote Earl Morris during his 1921 expedition into Forbidding Canyon. Morris had joined Charles L. Bernheimer's expedition to find an easier route between the main stem of the Colorado River and Rainbow Bridge, a natural arch which has captivated and drawn humans to it for millenia and is sacred for many Indigenous groups including the Navajo, Hopi, San Juan Southern Paiute, Kaibab Paiute, and White Mesa Ute. The group found little hope that Forbidding Canyon would make for an easier journey as it formed "a maze of tortuous canons winding in and out among dumpling-like knobs of rock, too hopelessly rough to be crossed" according to Morris. Eventually the group returned with dynamite to blast obstacles from their path. This trail became known as the Bernheimer trail. Forbidding Canyon flooded deep with water after Glen Canyon Dam was built, and it has now become the most visited tributary of Glen Canyon as 200,000-300,000 tourists motor boat through it to visit Rainbow Bridge.
subject: land; strata
personalnotes: here sediment carved a landscape that deeply affected how humans were able to move through space and which humans were able to access what. In this way, sediment created a defense-like maze to protects sacred sites like Rainbow Bridge. Now it is those very canyons that holds the water that allows for easy mobility of toursts.

originaltitle: The Crossing of the Fathers [This photo appears as a background image in Tad's Glen Canyon book on page 136.].

title: Building structure in Moqui Canyon
originaltitle: Moki Can. ruin - Undisturbed [Moqui Canyon].
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: Ancestral Puebloans dwelt in and around Glen Canyon for thousands of generations, building thousands of dwelling structures up and down the Canyon and its tributaries. These dwellings were typically constructed with stone fragments, by mixing sediment with water and straw to make adobe, and by utlizing the land's natural topographical features such as acloves or mesa tops.
subject: sediment; land; humans, dwellings; infrastructure; plants; water; strata
personalnotes: sediment formed people's homes--which when dissolved, returns back to the land. Also mixed with straw and water.

title: Construction of Glen Canyon Dam
originaltitle: [Looking down at construction below Glen Canyon Dam.]
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: The foundations of the Glen Canyon Dam were laid in the Colorado River's old bed. The river's water first had to be rerouted through temporary diversion tunnels, which took three years to dig. The diversion tunnels finished behind schedule as the soft sandstone continuously broke apart and collapsed into the tunnels. In 1958, for example, 5,200 cubic yards, or 500 dump trucks worth of sediment cleaved away in the left diversion tunnel. Much of the sand and rock used in Glen Canyon's concrete walls comes from Wahweep Canyon, which is a nearby tributary just five miles away from the dam site.
subject: infrastructure; dam; canyon
personalnotes: dam is made of sediment

title: Georgia O'Keeffe selecting stones on the shores of Lake Powell
originaltitle: [Georgia O'Keeffe selecting stones - Shore of Lake Powell.]
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: As Lake Powell began to fill, artist Georgia O'Keefe took several boat trips to visit the drowning canyon. She spent her time in the canyon painting, taking photographs, and collecting natural objects.
subject: humans; sediment; strata; land
outsideconnections: Photographer Todd Webb also remembers O'Keeffe in Glen Canyon in his memoirs, particularly a trip in August of 1961 that also included photographer, Eliot Porter. Frank Lloyd Wright wrote about their trips in his autobiography as well.

title: Ripple Laminae in Cottonwood Canyon
originaltitle: [Cottonwood Creek - Right bank, ripple laminae.]
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: Each layer of the sediment laminae was laid by a distinct geologic event--such as a spring flood which deposited a load of sediment all at once. The ripples forms are carved by water, and keep a record of the river's current. Ripples form as water erodes sediment on the upstream (stoss) side of a bank and quickly deposit it on the downstream (lee) side.  These scallop-shaped structures are called catenary ripples, which suggest a faster flow. Today there is no current in the bottom reaches of Cottonwood Canyon as it lies below Lake Powell.
subject: sediment

title: Tapestry Wall in Glen Canyon
originaltitle: [Tapestry wall in Glen Canyon.]
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: The vertical stripes on this canyon wall are known as desert varnish, and is commonly found on sandstone, particularly on north and east-facing walls. The varnish is composed of a thin gloss of sediment, minerals, and microbes interacting with one another over long periods of time, and is encouraged by water seeps, which might account for the striping patterns seen here. It takes more than 1,000 years for the varnish to accumulate to the width of a human hair. Much about the formation of desert varnish is still a mystery--it is not fully understood why varnish forms in some conditions and not others. Indigenous artists often chose varnished surfaces to etch petroglyphs as the underlying sandstone constrasted with the darknened varnish.
subject: sediment; land; strata

title: All My Rivers Are Gone: A Journey of Discovery Through Glen Canyon
creator: Lee, Katie

title: Potholes in sandstone
originaltitle: Potholes, sandstone. Glen Can.
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: Potholes are formed by water erosion, and mark places in the sandstone where sediment is not well cemented. Microbes often consume sandstone, which makes it susceptible to erosion. Water typically seeps through sandstone, but when it gathers in pools it is because the water is held in place by a biofilm of cyanobacteria, fungi, algae, and fine sediment. These ephemeral potholes in turn house diverse microecosystems which ancient and often endemic species rely upon for survival as they are free of fish and aquatic insect predators, and are often called "Mesozoic lifeboat niches”  Pothole animals have not evolved in hundreds of millions of years.
subject: sediment; land; water; weather

title: Sandstone steps
originaltitle: [Frank Wright on Schock Trail.]
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: Miners picked steps into Glen Canyon's soft sandstone walls in order to more easily access gold deposits. The history of mining in Glen Canyon begins with James Merrick and Ernst Mitchell, who searched the nearby Navajo Mountain and Monument Valley region in the 1870s for the source of silver that supplied Navajo jewelry-makers. In 1879, the men were killed by members of the Southern Paiute tribe. Two buttes nearby, which were sacred the Paitues, now bear their names. This event attracted attention to the region, especially from Cass Hite, who set out to search for the Merrick-Mitchell mine. With the help of a Navajo chief named Hoskinnini, Hite discovered placer gold near Dandy Crossing in 1883. Hundreds of miners rushed in, searching for gold at Wright sand bar. Hite sought investment and infrastructure to support gold mining in the canyon, prompting railroad construction by the Denver, Colorado, Canyon, and Pacificic Railroad Co. Robert B. Stanton sought to build a railroad from Grand Junction to Gulf of California and staked out five placer claims in doing so, including near the mouth of Hanson (Pine Alcove) creek. He named his mining company the Hoskannini Mining Co., establisehd in 1897 in Glen Canyon, which became the largest gold mining outfit in Glen Canyon. He became the second person to float from Green River through Glen Canyon while performing a railraod survey. By 1899, Stanton had 145 claims in glen Canyon, and bought a fleet of dredges in order to sift for gold dust in Glen Canyon's sand. He began dredge operations in 1901, but was stymied by variable water levels and his equipment's failure to capture gold dust. The silt-laden river water ate away at pump machinery and supply points were difficult due to the canyoned terrain. The project was abandoned. In 1909-1912, Charles H. Spencer and his American Placer Corp. prospected Lee's Ferry by sluicing, which was assisted by a pneumatic pipe which helped dredge sand and gravel for gold extraction, and processed the gold with almagamation, which involves mixing mecury to separate ore from gold. This process took place near the Paria River. The machinery was powered from coal, which was mined from Warren Creek, and transported at first by mule train, and then by steamboat, which did not last long as there was not enough coal to power the steam boat. Spencer ran into issues with the price of mercury, which was higher than the price of gold extraction, and his mine shut down. In the 1920s, oil prospecting and drilling took place, and in the 1950s uranium claims were staked up and down Glen Canyon. The deposits were too low to be profitable and so most prospects went undeveloped.
subject: sediment; mining; infrastructure
personalnotes: The steps are a trace of presence and absence: absence in that the land did not give up its material, presence in that the violence and imperialism are still inscribed on the land, in names and physical forms which later engendered the claims of the Colorado River compact. Sediment steps shows the allure hidden in its walls but also the way it stymies these endeavors. It remembers the violence and legends which have come and gone and become something new.

description: Robert B. Stanton sought to build a railroad from Grand Junction to Gulf of California and staked out five placer claims in doing so, including near the mouth of Hanson (Pine Alcove) creek. He named his mining company the Hoskannini Mining Co., establisehd in 1897 in Glen Canyon, which became the largest gold mining outfit in Glen Canyon, and staked the entire canyon from Hite to Lee's Ferry. His 26 workmen used Hole in the Rock to carry their 8,000lbs of equipment, and picked steps into the slickrock over the wagon trail. Stanton became the second person to float from Green River through Glen Canyon while performing a railraod survey. By 1899, Stanton had 145 claims in glen Canyon, and bought a fleet of dredges in order to sift for gold dust in Glen Canyon's sand. He began dredge operations in 1901, but was stymied by variable water levels and his equipment's failure to capture gold dust. The silt-laden river water ate away at pump machinery and supply points were difficult due to the canyoned terrain. The project was abandoned. In 1909-1912, Charles H. Spencer and his American Placer Corp. prospected Lee's Ferry by sluicing, which was assisted by a pneumatic pipe which helped dredge sand and gravel for gold extraction, and processed the gold with almagamation, which involves mixing mecury to separate ore from gold. This process took place near the Paria River. The machinery was powered from coal, which was mined from Warren Creek, and transported at first by mule train, and then by steamboat, which did not last long as there was not enough coal to power the steam boat. Spencer ran into issues with the price of mercury, which was higher than the price of gold extraction, and his mine shut down. In the 1920s, oil pros

title: Navajo Marbles
originaltitle: Navajo Marbles on Wild Horse Bar.
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: These are also called iron concretions, Navajo cherries, Navajo berries, Kayenta berries, Entrada berries, Moqui balls, or Shaman stones. They form in Navajo sandstone, when water with reducing agents (like acid or petroleum) moves through the permeable sandstone which dissolves the iron. The iron-water then flows and eventually the iron precipitates, cementing sand grains. They are made of concentric layers of iron and sand, and often times, microorganisms turn iron into iron oxide. The marbles are released as softer sandstone gets eroded away. Similar structures have been found on Mars, which scientists have lijnked to evidence of water and life.
subject: sediment; land; formations;

title: Steps to Inscription House

creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: Inscription house (Tsʼah Biiʼ Kin) was given its name because of the incsription left in 1661 by a Spanish Conquistador which reads "Shapeiro Ano Dom 1661," which Cummings and Wetherill documented in 1909.  Erosion has made it difficult to reach inscription house, washing burials and pottery into Lake Mead. It was constructed by Pueblos around 1200 AD, and inhabitatnts farmed corn, beans, and squash. It was built into a natural cave with access to a spring. It was closed due to erosion and for privacy.

personalnotes: this was on the Udall Trip. Udall approved the Dam initially, but later regretted this after seeing the Canyon. He later opposed Grand Canyon Dams.

title: Stewart Udall in Bridge Canyon
originaltitle: [Stewart and Lee Udall, their two boys, and Don Harris in Bridge Canyon - 1960.]
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
subject: sediment; wonder; atmosphere; land; infrastructure
personalnotes: Udall trip. Wonder. On August 9th they hiked to Rainbow Bridge where 'Udall walked to proposed upper protective dam, and climbed to top of Bridge.' They ended their trip at Kane Creek at 7PM that night, where a Bureau of Reclamation car was waiting to take them to a guest-house in Page.  Tad writes 'Udall was much imprest [sic] with Glen Canyon.'  He quotes Udall as saying that 'This should have been a Monument, Park, or better still, a wilderness area.' Tad also claims in his log that the legislator was 'against the protective dams for Rainbow.'  At the time of their trip, Stewart Udall was in his third term as Arizona's Representative to Congress. He won his fourth term in the fall of that year, and was soon after appointed Secretary of the Interior by John F. Kennedy.

title: Byron Cummings at Rainbow Bridge on August 8th, 1935
originaltitle: Cummings at Rainbow Bridge Aug 8th, 1935 [This photograph appears as a background image in Tad's Glen Canyon book on page 99.].
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
subject: sediment; formations; wonder; exploration
personalnotes: "Bryon Cummings, an archaeologist and professor of Greek and Latin at the University of Utah, and William Douglass, the general land surveyor for the USGS...[set] out to find [Rainbow Bridge] in 1909...It became a significant episode in the use of science in the name of preservation as a form of regional development. The discourse of discovery was often a precursor to the invention of a place in the historical imagination. Douglass wanted the region to remain 'wild' and 'undeveloped.'...Cumming's desire to claim the bridge was fueled by his academic ambition..." (Bsumek 68-69).

title: Lantern and Sewing Machine in California Bar Caves
originaltitle: Lantern and pedal sewing machine left behind by miners - Found inside one of the the California Bar caves. 'We Three' Trip - September/October 1955.[constructed title] [This image appears in Tad's Glen Canyon book on page 29.]
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: Placer miners set up shop on this flat sandy bar as they scraped out the canyon walls, looking for gold. The miners built houses out of rock, and even a grave for A.G. Turner, a miner who died on the bar. The bar was claimed by Hawthorn, Brown, Keeler, and Haskell, but passed into other hands, including the Chaffins. R.B. Stanton claimed in 1899 that $30,000 of gold were extracted from California Bar.

title: Old Rock Fireplace at Camp Stone
originaltitle: [Old rock fireplace and chimney at Camp Stone. This image appears in Tad's book-Glen Canyon Images of a Lost World- on page 30.]
creator: Nichols, Tad
repository: Special Collections and Archives, Cline Library, Northern Arizona University.
description: Robert Brewster Stanton first came to Glen Canyon in 1889 to survey the land a railroad construction project that would transport coal from Colorado to California and replace overseas markets. The scheme fell through when oil was discovered in Southern California, but Stanton remained in the Canyon after noticing "flour gold" in the river's sandbars. Stanton was employed by the Hoskaninni mining company and staked out the entire length of Glen Canyon and began to conduct assessments and began to dredge gold from the Canyon's alluvial fill. To bring the dredge machine, which was 105 feet long and 26 feet wide and weighted over 150 tons, crews hauled the machine down a road blasted out of Stanton Canyon and hauled by boat to Camp Stone, where the deredging would take place. Ten houses, a blacksmith shop, and an ice plant were constructed. A telephone was installed, fixed by wires drilled into the canyon wall Coal was brought in from the Henry Mountains. 75 men lived and worked at the site. The operation immediately ran into problems: as the river flucuated, the dredge would sink into the sand and have tob e hauled out. Additionally, the flour gold was so fine, once it was separated from the sand it would float to the top of the slurry and float back out into the river. By 1901, the dredge had been operating for 5 months and had made $30.15 in gold, coming up far short on the investment of over $100,000. Determined, Stanton continued, moving the dredge downstream to Wilson Canyon and attempted to fix the gasoline engines by removing them and placing htem on the river bank. The river undercut the bank and dropped the engines into the river. The camp became a salvage yard for other miners who salvaged material from the Camp.
subject: sediment; dwellings; mining
